titleStmt.title: Von Ludwig Wittgenstein an George Edward Moore, 18. 6. 1930
titleStmt.author: Wittgenstein, Ludwig

div.p: Thanks so much for the good news. I'm very grateful to the Council for its munificence.

I'm glad to hear you are enjoying your holydays. I don't yet enjoy mine, for I haven't yet been able to do any proper work, partly, I believe, due to the opressive heat we've had here during the last week or so, & partly because my brain simply won't work. I hope to God this state won't last long. It is very depressing when all the lights are put out as if there had never been any burning. However, I dare say it'll pass over. ‒ Would you be so very kind & take the Midsummer £50 for me & send them on to my Address? If it's not to[o] much trouble for you I should be very much obliged if you would.
I hope your vacation will continue satisfactorily & that mine will soon be allright too. I'ld be very glad if you would let me hear from you again some time how you're getting on etc.
